definition: to act in collusion (idiom)

to string together/to skewer/to connect wrongly/to gang up/to rove/string/bunch/skewer/classifier for things that are strung together, or in a bunch, or in a row: string of, bunch of, series of/to make a swift or abrupt linear movement (like a bead on an abacus)/to move across
to go through/to know well/(suffix) expert/to connect/to communicate/open/to clear/classifier for letters, telegrams, phone calls etc
classifier for an activity, taken in its entirety (tirade of abuse, stint of music playing, bout of drinking etc)
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
gas/air/smell/weather/to make angry/to annoy/to get angry/vital energy/qi

sentences.english: Several companies gang up to raise prices.
sentences.chinese: 几家公司串通一气抬高物价。

sentences.english: People always conspire to keep the truth from me.
sentences.chinese: 人们总是串通一气不把真情告诉我。

sentences.english: I know who rides with Théoden of Rohan.
sentences.chinese: 我知道谁跟罗翰国的塞奥顿串通一气。

definition: to collude/to collaborate/to gang up
to act in collusion (idiom); in cahoots with/villains will look after one another
to conspire/to plot together
to collude with/to collaborate with/to gang up with
villains collude together (idiom); to work hand in glove with sb (to nefarious ends)
jackals of the same tribe (idiom); fig. They are all just as bad as each other.
to incite/to stir up/to instigate
to harbor evil intentions (idiom)
harboring unfathomable motives (idiom)
lit. to sing a duet/fig. to collaborate with sb/also used satirically: to play second fiddle to
to sow dissension (idiom); to drive a wedge between
to play tricks/to cause mischief
to provoke
to shield/to harbor/to cover up
to defraud/to swindle
to use public office to avenge private wrongs
